prompt.p: Dietary deficiency is seldom the cause of iron deficiency anaemia.
Which of the following infections can lead to iron deficiency?

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Hookworm infestation) is Correct. Hookworm infestation is the commonest infestation to cause iron deficiency anaemia.

tr.td: Heavy periods are the most likely cause in young females

Bleeding peptic ulcer
Inflammatory bowel disease
Carcinoma of stomach, colon or rectum
Abnormal blood vessels in gut (angiodysplasia)
Malabsorption, e.g. coeliac disease
Hookworm infestation is commonest worldwide cause

Physiological demands e.g. growth spurts in children
Pregnancy

modalFeedback.p: Option A (Pneumonia) is Incorrect. Pneumonia per se does not cause iron deficiency anaemia, but prolonged debility can.
Option B (Meningitis) is Incorrect. Meningitis per se does not cause anaemia, but prolonged illness can.
Option D (Hepatitis) is Incorrect. Hepatitis by itself does not cause anaemia, but chronic liver disease can lead to a variety of anaemias.
Option E (Japanese encephalitis) is Incorrect. Japanese encephalitis is caused by the mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis virus. It is not associated with iron deficiency anaemia.
Option C (Hookworm infestation) is Correct. Hookworm infestation is the commonest infestation to cause iron deficiency anaemia.
